name: Syncope - Evaluation and Risk Stratification
content:
SYNCOPE:

DEFINITION:
- Transient loss of consciousness (TLOC)
- Rapid onset, short duration, spontaneous complete recovery
- Due to global cerebral hypoperfusion

CLASSIFICATION:

1. REFLEX (NEURALLY-MEDIATED) SYNCOPE (60%):
   - Vasovagal (most common): Emotional stress, pain, prolonged standing
   - Situational: Cough, micturition, defecation, post-exercise
   - Carotid sinus hypersensitivity
   Mechanism: Inappropriate reflex → bradycardia/vasodilation

2. ORTHOSTATIC HYPOTENSION (15%):
   - Volume depletion, medications (diuretics, vasodilators)
   - Autonomic failure (diabetes, Parkinson's, age)
   - Defined: SBP drop ≥20 mmHg or DBP ≥10 mmHg within 3min of standing

3. CARDIAC SYNCOPE (10-15%):
   a. Arrhythmic:
      - Bradycardia: Sinus node dysfunction, AV block
      - Tachycardia: VT, SVT, long QT, Brugada, WPW
   b. Structural:
      - Aortic stenosis, HCM, cardiac tamponade
      - Pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension
      - MI, aortic dissection
   Highest mortality risk

4. UNKNOWN CAUSE (10-15%)

EVALUATION:

INITIAL (All patients):
1. History: Detailed description of event, prodrome, triggers, position, recovery
2. Physical exam: Orthostatic vital signs, cardiac exam, neurologic exam
3. ECG: Assess for arrhythmia, conduction disease, structural disease

RED FLAGS (High-risk features):
- Age >60
- No prodrome (sudden onset)
- During exertion or supine
- Chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations
- Family history sudden cardiac death
- ECG abnormalities: LBBB, bifascicular block, QTc >500ms, Brugada pattern, epsilon waves, Q waves
- Structural heart disease, HF
- Severe anemia, electrolyte abnormality

ADDITIONAL TESTING (Based on suspicion):

1. CARDIAC:
   - Echocardiogram: If structural disease suspected
   - Telemetry/Holter: If arrhythmia suspected
   - Event recorder (30-day): If recurrent unexplained
   - Implantable loop recorder: Recurrent unexplained, high-risk
   - Exercise stress test: If exertional syncope
   - EP study: If high-risk ECG or known structural disease

2. ORTHOSTATIC:
   - Tilt table test: If vasovagal suspected
   - Autonomic testing

3. NEUROLOGIC (Rarely needed):
   - CT/MRI brain: Only if focal neurologic signs (not syncope)
   - EEG: Only if concern for seizure
   - Carotid ultrasound: Not routinely indicated

RISK STRATIFICATION - SAN FRANCISCO SYNCOPE RULE:
High risk if ANY:
- History of heart failure (C)
- Hematocrit <30% (H)
- Abnormal ECG (E)
- Shortness of breath (S)
- Systolic BP <90 mmHg (T)

Alternative: ROSE, OESIL, EGSYS scores

MANAGEMENT:

1. REFLEX SYNCOPE:
   - Education, reassurance
   - Avoid triggers, adequate hydration
   - Physical counterpressure maneuvers
   - Midodrine or fludrocortisone if severe recurrent

2. ORTHOSTATIC HYPOTENSION:
   - Adequate hydration (2-3L daily)
   - Increase salt intake
   - Compression stockings
   - Review/adjust medications
   - Midodrine, fludrocortisone, droxidopa

3. CARDIAC SYNCOPE:
   - Pacemaker: Bradycardia, AV block
   - ICD: Ventricular arrhythmias, high-risk cardiomyopathy
   - Ablation: Supraventricular tachycardias
   - Treat underlying structural disease

4. DRIVING RESTRICTIONS:
   - Cardiac syncope: 3-6 months until treated
   - Single vasovagal: May resume after counseling
   - Recurrent unexplained: Until diagnosis/treatment

PROGNOSIS:
- Reflex/orthostatic: Benign prognosis
- Cardiac: 1-year mortality 20-40%
- Overall recurrence: 30% at 3 years
